Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
a group of youths sneak into the woods, where they take mind-altering substances, switch it up romantically, and brush up against creatures 
from another dimension. "A Midsummer’s Night’s Dream" sees 
Shakespeare get psychedelic – and the result is a treat in the 
theatre and on the page. First performed in the 1590's, this play is one of Shakespeare’s 
friskiest works, filled with trickery, madness and magic. Set over the course of one night, Midsummer progresses at a rollicking pace. The plot is structured around patterns of 
collision and dissolution, where characters from different worlds 
are thrown together and torn apart. Shakespeare uses these patterns to mock 
the characters’ self-obsession and question authority with a comic twist. The action is set in Ancient Greece, but like many of Shakespeare’s plays 
it reflects his contemporary concerns. The magical setting of the woods at night disrupts the boundaries between 
separate groups, with bizarre results. Here, the bard plays with the rigid class 
system of his own time, taking three distinct groups
and turning their society upside-down in a world where no mortal is in control. The play opens with young Hermia raging at her father Egeus and 
Theseus, the King of Athens, who have forbidden her to marry 
her lover Lysander. Hermia has no interest in her father's 
choice for her of Demetrius – but her best friend Helena 
definitely does. Furious at their elders, Hermia and 
Lysander elope under cover of darkness, with Demetrius in hot pursuit. This is further complicated 
by Helena’s decision to follow them all into the woods,
in the hope of winning Demetrius’ heart. At this point, the woods are 
getting crowded, as the lovers are sharing the space 
with a group of “rude mechanicals”— a troupe of workers drunkenly rehearsing 
a play, led by the jovial Nick Bottom. Unbeknownst to them, the humans have 
entered into the world of the fairies. Despite their magical splendor, 
Oberon and Titania, the king and queen of the fairies, 
have their own romantic problems. Furious at his inability to control 
Titania, the jealous Oberon commands the trickster Puck to squeeze the
juice of a magical flower over her eyes. When she wakes up, she’ll fall in love 
with the first thing she sees. On his mission, Puck gleefully sprinkles the juice over
the eyes of the napping Demetrius and Lysander, and transforms Bottom’s head
into that of a donkey for good measure. As eyes flicker open, a night of chaos commences that includes
broken hearts, mistaken identity, and transformations. Out of all the characters, Bottom probably
fares the best – when the bewitched Titania 
lays eyes on him, she calls on her fairies to lavish him 
with wine and treasures and sweeps the transfigured donkeyman 
off his feet: “pluck the wings from painted butterflies/ To fan the moonbeams 
from his sleeping eyes. Nod to him, elves, 
and do him courtesies.” While magic is the catalyst to the action, the play reflects the real drama 
of the things we do for love – and the nonsensical behavior 
of the people under its spell. The moon overlooks the action 
“like a silver bow,” signifying erratic behavior, 
the dark side of love, and the bewitching allure of a world 
where the usual rules don’t apply. Although the characters eventually 
come to their senses, "A Midsummer Night's Dream" 
raises the question of how much agency we have 
over our own daily lives. But it’s not the more realistically
rendered lovers, rulers or workers who have the last word, but the impish Puck who queries whether we
can ever truly trust what we see: If we shadows have offended, Think but this and all is mended: That you have but slumbered here While these visions did appear.  And in so doing, he evokes the effect of entering into the 
magical world of great theatre that plays with the boundary between 
illusion and reality – and dramatizes the possibility 
that life is but a dream.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where is a Midsummer Night's Dream set?
Options: A. Mantua, B. Ancient Rome, C. Ancient Greece, D. Elizabethan England
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many people and dogs are estimated to be on Earth today? Options: A. 1 billion people and 200 million dogs, B. 7.4 billion people and 200 million dogs, C. 7.4 billion people and 100 million dogs, D. 1 billion people and 100 million dogs Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the estimated number of humans that would be around today if we didn't have domestication? Options: A. 1 million, B. 2 million, C. 5 million, D. 10 million Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main reason why scientists are still trying to figure out when and where dogs were domesticated? Options: A. Because dog genes have mixed so much, making it difficult to pinpoint a single origin, B. Because fossils don't tell the whole story, C. Because there is no evidence of dog domestication, D. All of the above Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the most likely reason why humans didn't adopt dogs, but dogs adopted us? Options: A. Because early humans killed off most carnivorous competition, B. Because wolves and humans were hunting buddies, C. Because wolf packs can hunt just fine on their own, D. Because dogs didn't needed humans, but humans' leftovers could have made their lives easier Correct Option: D
Question 5: What percentage of domestic dogs still survive on human waste? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 50%, D. 85% Correct Option: D
Question 6: According to DNA in mitochondria, when did dogs split from their wolf ancestors? Options: A. Around 33,000 years ago, B. Between 19 and 32 thousand years ago, C. 12,000 years ago, D. 50,000 years ago Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the main challenge in determining when and where dogs were domesticated? Options: A. Because dog genes have mixed so much, making it difficult to pinpoint a single origin, B. Because fossils don't tell the whole story, C. Because there is no evidence of dog domestication, D. All of the above Correct Option: A
Question 8: What roles did dogs play in human society? Options: A. They were used as herders, sled pullers, and guards, B. They were used as emergency food supply, C. They were used as hunting buddies, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the estimated number of dog breeds that have been crafted from a wolf mold? Options: A. 100, B. 200, C. 300, D. 340 Correct Option: D
Question 10: Why is it difficult to determine where the domestication of dogs began? Options: A. Because there is no evidence of dog domestication, B. Because dog genes have mixed so much, C. Because fossils don't tell the whole story, D. Because the story of dog domestication is tightly wound to human history, making it difficult to distinguish between human and canine influences Correct Option: D

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Question 3: What is the main reason why scientists are still trying to figure out when and where dogs were domesticated? Options: A. Because dog genes have mixed so much, making it difficult to pinpoint a single origin, B. Because fossils don't tell the whole story, C. Because there is no evidence of dog domestication, D. All of the above Correct Option: A

Because wolves and humans were hunting buddies, C. Because wolf packs can hunt just fine on their own, D. Because dogs didn't needed humans, but humans' leftovers could have made their lives easier Correct Option: D
Question 5: What percentage of domestic dogs still survive on human waste? Options: A. 10%, B. 20%, C. 50%, D. 85% Correct Option: D
Question 6: According to DNA in mitochondria, when did dogs split from their wolf ancestors? Options: A. Around 33,000 years ago, B. Between 19 and 32 thousand years ago, C. 12,000 years ago, D. 50,000 years ago Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the main challenge in determining when and where dogs were domesticated? Options: A. Because dog genes have mixed so much, making it difficult to pinpoint a single origin, B. Because fossils don't tell the whole story, C. Because there is no evidence of dog domestication, D. All of the above Correct Option: A
Question 8: What roles did dogs play in human society? Options: A. They were used as herders, sled pullers, and guards, B. They were used as emergency food supply, C. They were used as hunting buddies, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the estimated number of dog breeds that have been crafted from a wolf mold? Options: A. 100, B. 200, C. 300, D. 340 Correct Option: D
Question 10: Why is it difficult to determine where the domestication of dogs began? Options: A. Because there is no evidence of dog domestication, B. Because dog genes have mixed so much, C. Because fossils don't tell the whole story, D. Because the story of dog domestication is tightly wound to human history, making it difficult to distinguish between human and canine influences Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
a group of youths sneak into the woods, where they take mind-altering substances, switch it up romantically, and brush up against creatures 
from another dimension. "A Midsummer’s Night’s Dream" sees 
Shakespeare get psychedelic – and the result is a treat in the 
theatre and on the page. First performed in the 1590's, this play is one of Shakespeare’s 
friskiest works, filled with trickery, madness and magic. Set over the course of one night, Midsummer progresses at a rollicking pace. The plot is structured around patterns of 
collision and dissolution, where characters from different worlds 
are thrown together and torn apart. Shakespeare uses these patterns to mock 
the characters’ self-obsession and question authority with a comic twist. The action is set in Ancient Greece, but like many of Shakespeare’s plays 
it reflects his contemporary concerns. The magical setting of the woods at night disrupts the boundaries between 
separate groups, with bizarre results. Here, the bard plays with the rigid class 
system of his own time, taking three distinct groups
and turning their society upside-down in a world where no mortal is in control. The play opens with young Hermia raging at her father Egeus and 
Theseus, the King of Athens, who have forbidden her to marry 
her lover Lysander. Hermia has no interest in her father's 
choice for her of Demetrius – but her best friend Helena 
definitely does. Furious at their elders, Hermia and 
Lysander elope under cover of darkness, with Demetrius in hot pursuit. This is further complicated 
by Helena’s decision to follow them all into the woods,
in the hope of winning Demetrius’ heart. At this point, the woods are 
getting crowded, as the lovers are sharing the space 
with a group of “rude mechanicals”— a troupe of workers drunkenly rehearsing 
a play, led by the jovial Nick Bottom. Unbeknownst to them, the humans have 
entered into the world of the fairies. Despite their magical splendor, 
Oberon and Titania, the king and queen of the fairies, 
have their own romantic problems. Furious at his inability to control 
Titania, the jealous Oberon commands the trickster Puck to squeeze the
juice of a magical flower over her eyes. When she wakes up, she’ll fall in love 
with the first thing she sees. On his mission, Puck gleefully sprinkles the juice over
the eyes of the napping Demetrius and Lysander, and transforms Bottom’s head
into that of a donkey for good measure. As eyes flicker open, a night of chaos commences that includes
broken hearts, mistaken identity, and transformations. Out of all the characters, Bottom probably
fares the best – when the bewitched Titania 
lays eyes on him, she calls on her fairies to lavish him 
with wine and treasures and sweeps the transfigured donkeyman 
off his feet: “pluck the wings from painted butterflies/ To fan the moonbeams 
from his sleeping eyes. Nod to him, elves, 
and do him courtesies.” While magic is the catalyst to the action, the play reflects the real drama 
of the things we do for love – and the nonsensical behavior 
of the people under its spell. The moon overlooks the action 
“like a silver bow,” signifying erratic behavior, 
the dark side of love, and the bewitching allure of a world 
where the usual rules don’t apply. Although the characters eventually 
come to their senses, "A Midsummer Night's Dream" 
raises the question of how much agency we have 
over our own daily lives. But it’s not the more realistically
rendered lovers, rulers or workers who have the last word, but the impish Puck who queries whether we
can ever truly trust what we see: If we shadows have offended, Think but this and all is mended: That you have but slumbered here While these visions did appear.  And in so doing, he evokes the effect of entering into the 
magical world of great theatre that plays with the boundary between 
illusion and reality – and dramatizes the possibility 
that life is but a dream.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who is the character with the last word in the play?
Options: A. Demetrius, B. Titania, C. Oberon, D. Puck
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Billy Pilgrim can’t sleep because he knows aliens will arrive
to abduct him in one hour. He knows the aliens are coming because
he has become “unstuck” in time, causing him to experience
events out of chronological order. Over the course of Kurt Vonnegut’s 
Slaughterhouse-five, he hops back and forth between a childhood
trip to the Grand Canyon, his life as a middle-aged optometrist, his captivity in an intergalactic zoo, the humiliations he endured
as a war prisoner, and more. The title of Slaughterhouse-five and 
much of its source material came from Vonnegut’s own 
experiences in World War II. As a prisoner of war, he lived in a former
slaughterhouse in Dresden, where he took refuge in an 
underground meat locker while Allied forces bombed the city. When he and the other prisoners
finally emerged, they found Dresden utterly demolished. After the war, Vonnegut tried to 
make sense of human behavior by studying an unusual 
aspect of anthropology: the shapes of stories, which he insisted were just as interesting
as the shapes of pots or spearheads. To find the shape, he graphed the main 
character’s fortune from the beginning to the end of a story. The zany curves he generated revealed 
common types of fairy tales and myths that echo through many cultures. But this shape can be
the most interesting of all. In a story like this, it’s impossible to distinguish the 
character’s good fortune from the bad. Vonnegut thought this kind of story 
was the truest to real life, in which we are all the victims 
of a series of accidents, unable to predict how events 
will impact us long term. He found the tidy, satisfying arcs of 
many stories at odds with this reality, and he set out to explore the ambiguity between good and bad fortune
in his own work. When Vonnegut ditched clear-cut fortunes, he also abandoned
straightforward chronology. Instead of proceeding tidily from 
beginning to end, in his stories “All moments, past, present and future 
always have existed, always will exist.” Tralfamadorians, the aliens who crop up
in many of his books, see all moments at once. They “can see where each star has been
and where it is going, so that the heavens are filled
with rarefied, luminous spaghetti.” But although they can see all of time, they don’t try to change 
the course of events. While the Trafalmadorians may be at peace 
with their lack of agency, Vonnegut’s human characters are 
still getting used to it. In The Sirens of Titan, when they seek the meaning of life
in the vastness of the universe, they find nothing but “empty heroics, 
low comedy, and pointless death.” Then, from their vantage point within 
a “chrono-synclastic infundibulum,” a man and his dog see devastating 
futures for their earthly counterparts, but can’t change the course of events. Though there aren’t easy answers 
available, they eventually conclude that the purpose of life is “to love
whoever is around to be loved.” In Cat’s Cradle, Vonnegut’s characters 
turn to a different source of meaning: Bokonism, a religion based on harmless lies 
that all its adherents recognize as lies. Though they’re aware of Bokonism’s lies, they live their lives by 
these tenets anyway, and in so doing develop
some genuine hope. They join together in groups called 
Karasses, which consist of people we “find by accident but […] 
stick with by choice”— cosmically linked around
a shared purpose. These are not to be confused 
with Granfalloons, groups of people who appoint significance
to actually meaningless associations, like where you grew up, political 
parties, and even entire nations. Though he held a bleak view of the human 
condition, Vonnegut believed strongly that “we are all here to help each other get
through this thing, whatever it is." We might get pooped and demoralized, but Vonnegut interspersed 
his grim assessments with more than a few morsels of hope. His fictional alter ego, Kilgore Trout, 
supplied this parable: two yeast sat “discussing the
possible purposes of life as they ate sugar and suffocated 
in their own excrement. Because of their limited intelligence, they never came close to guessing 
that they were making champagne.” In spite of his insistence that we’re
all here to fart around, in spite of his deep concerns about 
the course of human existence, Vonnegut also advanced the possibility, 
however slim, that we might end up 
making something good. And if that isn’t nice, what is?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Slaughterhouse-Five got its name from Kurt Vonnegut’s own experience with what?
Options: A. Working in Building #5 of a meat factory in Utica, NY, B. Living as a prisoner of war in a former slaughterhouse in Dresden, Germany, C. Dreaming about time travel to the fifth planet from the sun, D. Campaigning against animal slaughter with the Humanist Society of America
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is James Bridle's profession, and how does he use technology in his work? Options: A. He is a writer and artist who creates interactive installations., B. He is a writer and artist who uses technology to create work about technology, including drawing life-size outlines of military drones and building a self-driving car., C. He is a software engineer who creates algorithms for social media platforms., D. He is a documentary filmmaker who uses technology to tell stories about social issues. Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to James, what is the main way people get views on their videos on YouTube? Options: A. By making high-quality content., B. By using popular terms in their video titles and stuffing them with keywords, making them meaningless to humans but optimized for software., C. By purchasing advertising space., D. By engaging with their audience. Correct Option: B
Question 3: James mentions the "Finger Family Song" as an example of a popular kids' YouTube video. What is distinctive about this song? Options: A. It has a catchy melody., B. It is a classic children's song., C. It has an earwormy tune that can be stuck in one's head., D. It is a song from a popular kids' TV show. Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to James, what is the impact of surprise egg videos on children? Options: A. They are entertaining and educational., B. They are addictive and can lead to behavioral problems, including screaming and tantrums when the screen is taken away., C. They are a good way to teach children about science., D. They are a popular way for children to learn new skills. Correct Option: B
Question 5: James suggests that the YouTube algorithm is being used to "hack the brains of very small children" for advertising revenue. What is the primary mechanism behind this? Options: A. The use of catchy music and colorful visuals., B. The repetition of certain keywords and phrases in video titles., C. The deployment of AI-powered moderation tools., D. The use of popular terms in video titles. Correct Option: B
Question 6: James argues that the concentration of power in a few hands leads to violence and exploitation. What is the primary cause of this issue, according to James? Options: A. The lack of regulation and oversight., B. The concentration of power in a few hands., C. The use of technology to manipulate people., D. The lack of digital literacy among users. Correct Option: B
Question 7: James suggests that technology should be viewed as a guide to understanding our problems, rather than a solution to them. What is the primary implication of this perspective? Options: A. That technology should be used to solve all our problems., B. That technology should be viewed as a neutral tool., C. That technology should be used to understand our problems and then addressed properly., D. That technology should be discarded altogether. Correct Option: C
Question 8: According to James, what is the key to improving the systems that are currently in place? Options: A. Increasing the use of AI-powered moderation tools., B. Making the systems more legible to users by increasing digital literacy and transparency., C. Increasing the concentration of power in a few hands., D. Decreasing the use of digital technology. Correct Option: B
Question 9: James suggests that education is a collective responsibility. What is the primary implication of this perspective? Options: A. That education should be left to the experts., B. That education should be a top-down process., C. That education should be a consensual discussion among all stakeholders, including users, developers, and policymakers., D. That education should be a one-size-fits-all approach. Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to James, what is the primary challenge facing society in terms of technology? Options: A. The lack of regulation and oversight., B. The concentration of power in a few hands, leading to inequality and exploitation., C. The use of technology to manipulate people., D. The lack of digital literacy among users. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can tell you that the generated MCQs seem to be related to a different topic, likely a transcript about James Bridle and his views on technology.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the question format and style, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match. However, the content and options are completely unrelated to the ground truth MCQ.

Therefore, I would not recommend matching any of the generated MCQs with the ground truth MCQ. Instead, I would suggest generating new MCQs that are specifically designed to match the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which shape of story curve did Kurt Vonnegut consider the most interesting?
Options: A. A flat horizontal line, B. A zany curve, C. A staircase and sudden drop, D. A perfect slope upward

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Billy Pilgrim can’t sleep because he knows aliens will arrive
to abduct him in one hour. He knows the aliens are coming because
he has become “unstuck” in time, causing him to experience
events out of chronological order. Over the course of Kurt Vonnegut’s 
Slaughterhouse-five, he hops back and forth between a childhood
trip to the Grand Canyon, his life as a middle-aged optometrist, his captivity in an intergalactic zoo, the humiliations he endured
as a war prisoner, and more. The title of Slaughterhouse-five and 
much of its source material came from Vonnegut’s own 
experiences in World War II. As a prisoner of war, he lived in a former
slaughterhouse in Dresden, where he took refuge in an 
underground meat locker while Allied forces bombed the city. When he and the other prisoners
finally emerged, they found Dresden utterly demolished. After the war, Vonnegut tried to 
make sense of human behavior by studying an unusual 
aspect of anthropology: the shapes of stories, which he insisted were just as interesting
as the shapes of pots or spearheads. To find the shape, he graphed the main 
character’s fortune from the beginning to the end of a story. The zany curves he generated revealed 
common types of fairy tales and myths that echo through many cultures. But this shape can be
the most interesting of all. In a story like this, it’s impossible to distinguish the 
character’s good fortune from the bad. Vonnegut thought this kind of story 
was the truest to real life, in which we are all the victims 
of a series of accidents, unable to predict how events 
will impact us long term. He found the tidy, satisfying arcs of 
many stories at odds with this reality, and he set out to explore the ambiguity between good and bad fortune
in his own work. When Vonnegut ditched clear-cut fortunes, he also abandoned
straightforward chronology. Instead of proceeding tidily from 
beginning to end, in his stories “All moments, past, present and future 
always have existed, always will exist.” Tralfamadorians, the aliens who crop up
in many of his books, see all moments at once. They “can see where each star has been
and where it is going, so that the heavens are filled
with rarefied, luminous spaghetti.” But although they can see all of time, they don’t try to change 
the course of events. While the Trafalmadorians may be at peace 
with their lack of agency, Vonnegut’s human characters are 
still getting used to it. In The Sirens of Titan, when they seek the meaning of life
in the vastness of the universe, they find nothing but “empty heroics, 
low comedy, and pointless death.” Then, from their vantage point within 
a “chrono-synclastic infundibulum,” a man and his dog see devastating 
futures for their earthly counterparts, but can’t change the course of events. Though there aren’t easy answers 
available, they eventually conclude that the purpose of life is “to love
whoever is around to be loved.” In Cat’s Cradle, Vonnegut’s characters 
turn to a different source of meaning: Bokonism, a religion based on harmless lies 
that all its adherents recognize as lies. Though they’re aware of Bokonism’s lies, they live their lives by 
these tenets anyway, and in so doing develop
some genuine hope. They join together in groups called 
Karasses, which consist of people we “find by accident but […] 
stick with by choice”— cosmically linked around
a shared purpose. These are not to be confused 
with Granfalloons, groups of people who appoint significance
to actually meaningless associations, like where you grew up, political 
parties, and even entire nations. Though he held a bleak view of the human 
condition, Vonnegut believed strongly that “we are all here to help each other get
through this thing, whatever it is." We might get pooped and demoralized, but Vonnegut interspersed 
his grim assessments with more than a few morsels of hope. His fictional alter ego, Kilgore Trout, 
supplied this parable: two yeast sat “discussing the
possible purposes of life as they ate sugar and suffocated 
in their own excrement. Because of their limited intelligence, they never came close to guessing 
that they were making champagne.” In spite of his insistence that we’re
all here to fart around, in spite of his deep concerns about 
the course of human existence, Vonnegut also advanced the possibility, 
however slim, that we might end up 
making something good. And if that isn’t nice, what is?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do the Tralfamadorians in Vonnegut’s books understand time?
Options: A. They see time as a linear progression, B. They don’t see time at all, C. They see all moments at once, D. They only see the past
Correct Option: C

He is a writer and artist who uses technology to create work about technology, including drawing life-size outlines of military drones and building a self-driving car., C. He is a software engineer who creates algorithms for social media platforms., D. He is a documentary filmmaker who uses technology to tell stories about social issues. Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to James, what is the main way people get views on their videos on YouTube? Options: A. By making high-quality content., B. By using popular terms in their video titles and stuffing them with keywords, making them meaningless to humans but optimized for software., C. By purchasing advertising space., D. By engaging with their audience. Correct Option: B

It is a classic children's song., C. It has an earwormy tune that can be stuck in one's head., D. It is a song from a popular kids' TV show. Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to James, what is the impact of surprise egg videos on children? Options: A. They are entertaining and educational., B. They are addictive and can lead to behavioral problems, including screaming and tantrums when the screen is taken away., C. They are a good way to teach children about science., D. They are a popular way for children to learn new skills. Correct Option: B
Question 5: James suggests that the YouTube algorithm is being used to "hack the brains of very small children" for advertising revenue. What is the primary mechanism behind this? Options: A. The use of catchy music and colorful visuals., B. The repetition of certain keywords and phrases in video titles., C. The deployment of AI-powered moderation tools., D. The use of popular terms in video titles. Correct Option: B
Question 6: James argues that the concentration of power in a few hands leads to violence and exploitation. What is the primary cause of this issue, according to James? Options: A. The lack of regulation and oversight., B. The concentration of power in a few hands., C. The use of technology to manipulate people., D. The lack of digital literacy among users. Correct Option: B
Question 7: James suggests that technology should be viewed as a guide to understanding our problems, rather than a solution to them. What is the primary implication of this perspective? Options: A. That technology should be used to solve all our problems., B. That technology should be viewed as a neutral tool., C. That technology should be used to understand our problems and then addressed properly., D. That technology should be discarded altogether. Correct Option: C
Question 8: According to James, what is the key to improving the systems that are currently in place? Options: A. Increasing the use of AI-powered moderation tools., B. Making the systems more legible to users by increasing digital literacy and transparency., C. Increasing the concentration of power in a few hands., D. Decreasing the use of digital technology. Correct Option: B
Question 9: James suggests that education is a collective responsibility. What is the primary implication of this perspective? Options: A. That education should be left to the experts., B. That education should be a top-down process., C. That education should be a consensual discussion among all stakeholders, including users, developers, and policymakers., D. That education should be a one-size-fits-all approach. Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to James, what is the primary challenge facing society in terms of technology? Options: A. The lack of regulation and oversight., B. The concentration of power in a few hands, leading to inequality and exploitation., C. The use of technology to manipulate people., D. The lack of digital literacy among users. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Billy Pilgrim can’t sleep because he knows aliens will arrive
to abduct him in one hour. He knows the aliens are coming because
he has become “unstuck” in time, causing him to experience
events out of chronological order. Over the course of Kurt Vonnegut’s 
Slaughterhouse-five, he hops back and forth between a childhood
trip to the Grand Canyon, his life as a middle-aged optometrist, his captivity in an intergalactic zoo, the humiliations he endured
as a war prisoner, and more. The title of Slaughterhouse-five and 
much of its source material came from Vonnegut’s own 
experiences in World War II. As a prisoner of war, he lived in a former
slaughterhouse in Dresden, where he took refuge in an 
underground meat locker while Allied forces bombed the city. When he and the other prisoners
finally emerged, they found Dresden utterly demolished. After the war, Vonnegut tried to 
make sense of human behavior by studying an unusual 
aspect of anthropology: the shapes of stories, which he insisted were just as interesting
as the shapes of pots or spearheads. To find the shape, he graphed the main 
character’s fortune from the beginning to the end of a story. The zany curves he generated revealed 
common types of fairy tales and myths that echo through many cultures. But this shape can be
the most interesting of all. In a story like this, it’s impossible to distinguish the 
character’s good fortune from the bad. Vonnegut thought this kind of story 
was the truest to real life, in which we are all the victims 
of a series of accidents, unable to predict how events 
will impact us long term. He found the tidy, satisfying arcs of 
many stories at odds with this reality, and he set out to explore the ambiguity between good and bad fortune
in his own work. When Vonnegut ditched clear-cut fortunes, he also abandoned
straightforward chronology. Instead of proceeding tidily from 
beginning to end, in his stories “All moments, past, present and future 
always have existed, always will exist.” Tralfamadorians, the aliens who crop up
in many of his books, see all moments at once. They “can see where each star has been
and where it is going, so that the heavens are filled
with rarefied, luminous spaghetti.” But although they can see all of time, they don’t try to change 
the course of events. While the Trafalmadorians may be at peace 
with their lack of agency, Vonnegut’s human characters are 
still getting used to it. In The Sirens of Titan, when they seek the meaning of life
in the vastness of the universe, they find nothing but “empty heroics, 
low comedy, and pointless death.” Then, from their vantage point within 
a “chrono-synclastic infundibulum,” a man and his dog see devastating 
futures for their earthly counterparts, but can’t change the course of events. Though there aren’t easy answers 
available, they eventually conclude that the purpose of life is “to love
whoever is around to be loved.” In Cat’s Cradle, Vonnegut’s characters 
turn to a different source of meaning: Bokonism, a religion based on harmless lies 
that all its adherents recognize as lies. Though they’re aware of Bokonism’s lies, they live their lives by 
these tenets anyway, and in so doing develop
some genuine hope. They join together in groups called 
Karasses, which consist of people we “find by accident but […] 
stick with by choice”— cosmically linked around
a shared purpose. These are not to be confused 
with Granfalloons, groups of people who appoint significance
to actually meaningless associations, like where you grew up, political 
parties, and even entire nations. Though he held a bleak view of the human 
condition, Vonnegut believed strongly that “we are all here to help each other get
through this thing, whatever it is." We might get pooped and demoralized, but Vonnegut interspersed 
his grim assessments with more than a few morsels of hope. His fictional alter ego, Kilgore Trout, 
supplied this parable: two yeast sat “discussing the
possible purposes of life as they ate sugar and suffocated 
in their own excrement. Because of their limited intelligence, they never came close to guessing 
that they were making champagne.” In spite of his insistence that we’re
all here to fart around, in spite of his deep concerns about 
the course of human existence, Vonnegut also advanced the possibility, 
however slim, that we might end up 
making something good. And if that isn’t nice, what is?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In Sirens of Titan, when confronted with their lack of agency, characters ultimately realize that:
Options: A. Life is purposeless and they should make no effort, B. Time travel is the only way to be happy, C. The purpose of life is to love whomever is around to be loved, D. Life is a dream and they will eventually wake up
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The family of giants you work for is throwing a fancy dinner party, and they all want to look their best. But there’s a problem – the elder giant’s favorite 
shirt is wrinkled! To fix it, you’ll need to power up… the Giant Iron. The iron needs two giant 
batteries to work. You just had 4 working ones and 4 dead ones in separate piles, but it looks like the baby giant 
mixed them all up. You need to get the iron working 
and press the giant shirt, fast – or you’ll end up being the 
main course tonight! How can you test the batteries so that you’re guaranteed to get 
a working pair in 7 tries or less? Pause the video now if you want to 
figure it out for yourself Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 You could, of course, take 
all eight batteries and begin testing the 28 
possible combinations. You might get lucky within 
the first few tries. But if you don’t, moving the giant 
batteries that many times will take way too long. You can’t rely on luck – you need to assume the worst 
possibility and plan accordingly. However, you don’t actually need 
to test every possible combination. Remember – there are four 
good batteries in total, meaning that any pile of six you choose will have at least two 
good batteries in it. That doesn’t help you right away, since testing all six batteries could 
still take as many as 15 tries. But it does give you 
a clue to the solution – dividing the batteries into smaller 
subsets narrows down the possible results. So instead of six batteries, let’s take any three. This group has a total of three 
possible combinations. Since both batteries have to be 
working for the iron to power up, a single failure can’t tell you whether 
both batteries are dead, or just one. But if all three combinations fail, then you’ll know this group has either 
one good battery, or none at all. Now you can set those three aside and repeat the process for 
another three batteries. You might get a match, but if every 
combination fails again, you’ll know this set can have 
no more than one good battery. That would leave only two 
batteries untried. Since there are four good 
batteries in total and you’ve only accounted for two so far, both of these remaining ones must be good. Dividing the batteries into 
sets of 3, 3, and 2 is guaranteed to get a working result 
in 7 tries or less, no matter what order 
you test the piles in. With no time to spare, 
the iron comes to life, and you manage to get the shirt 
flawlessly ironed. The pleased elder and his family show up 
to the party dressed to the nines … well, almost.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many working batteries are there?
Options: A. 2, B. 4, C. 6, D. 8
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the result of a massive star running out of fuel and collapsing under its own gravitational pressure? Options: A. The explosion of a supernova, B. The creation of a black hole, C. The formation of a neutron star, D. The expansion of the galaxy Correct Option: C
Question 2: Describe the composition of a neutron star. Options: A. A compact ball of protons and electrons, B. A dense ball of matter with atomic electrons collapsed into atomic nuclei, C. A collection of heavy elements, D. A frictionless liquid of neutrons surrounded by a crust Correct Option: D
Question 3: How do neutron stars often behave before they collapse? Options: A. They undergo nuclear fission, B. They experience gravitational waves, C. They spin rapidly, D. They emit gamma rays Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the reason for the rapid spin of a neutron star compared to its parent star? Options: A. The increase in mass, B. The decrease in size, C. The change in magnetic field, D. The conservation of angular momentum Correct Option: D
Question 5: What happens to an aging neutron star's furious rotation over billions of years? Options: A. It speeds up, B. It remains the same, C. It increases in size, D. It slows down due to the emission of electromagnetic and gravity waves Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the significance of the detection of a pulsar by astrophysicist Jocelyn Bell in 1967? Options: A. It was the first observation of a binary system, B. It was the first detection of a supernova, C. It was the first observation of a black hole, D. It was the first indirect discovery of a neutron star Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the result of a neutron star collision, as predicted by Einstein's theory of General Relativity? Options: A. The emission of gamma rays, B. The formation of a black hole, C. The emission of gravity waves, D. The increase in mass Correct Option: C
Question 8: What did the observation of a neutron star collision by LIGO and VIRGO in 2017 provide evidence for? Options: A. The origin of heavy elements, B. Important theories in astrophysics, C. The speed of gravity, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the purpose of upgrading LIGO and VIRGO to detect more collisions? Options: A. To study the properties of black holes, B. To observe the formation of supernovae, C. To learn more about the universe and the properties of neutron stars, D. To detect the emission of gamma rays Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of neutron stars in the universe? Options: A. They are the most massive objects in the universe, B. They are the most luminous objects in the universe, C. They are the densest objects in the universe, D. They are the most mysterious objects in the universe Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. However, I will provide the index of the generated MCQ that is least dissimilar.

The ground truth MCQ is asking about the number of working batteries, which is a specific detail from the transcript. The generated MCQs are all about neutron stars and astrophysics, which is completely unrelated to the transcript.

If I had to choose, I would say that Question 5 is the least dissimilar, but only because it is asking about a specific quantity (the rotation of a neutron star) and has numerical options, similar to the ground truth MCQ. However, the content and intent of the question are still completely different.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The family of giants you work for is throwing a fancy dinner party, and they all want to look their best. But there’s a problem – the elder giant’s favorite 
shirt is wrinkled! To fix it, you’ll need to power up… the Giant Iron. The iron needs two giant 
batteries to work. You just had 4 working ones and 4 dead ones in separate piles, but it looks like the baby giant 
mixed them all up. You need to get the iron working 
and press the giant shirt, fast – or you’ll end up being the 
main course tonight! How can you test the batteries so that you’re guaranteed to get 
a working pair in 7 tries or less? Pause the video now if you want to 
figure it out for yourself Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 You could, of course, take 
all eight batteries and begin testing the 28 
possible combinations. You might get lucky within 
the first few tries. But if you don’t, moving the giant 
batteries that many times will take way too long. You can’t rely on luck – you need to assume the worst 
possibility and plan accordingly. However, you don’t actually need 
to test every possible combination. Remember – there are four 
good batteries in total, meaning that any pile of six you choose will have at least two 
good batteries in it. That doesn’t help you right away, since testing all six batteries could 
still take as many as 15 tries. But it does give you 
a clue to the solution – dividing the batteries into smaller 
subsets narrows down the possible results. So instead of six batteries, let’s take any three. This group has a total of three 
possible combinations. Since both batteries have to be 
working for the iron to power up, a single failure can’t tell you whether 
both batteries are dead, or just one. But if all three combinations fail, then you’ll know this group has either 
one good battery, or none at all. Now you can set those three aside and repeat the process for 
another three batteries. You might get a match, but if every 
combination fails again, you’ll know this set can have 
no more than one good battery. That would leave only two 
batteries untried. Since there are four good 
batteries in total and you’ve only accounted for two so far, both of these remaining ones must be good. Dividing the batteries into 
sets of 3, 3, and 2 is guaranteed to get a working result 
in 7 tries or less, no matter what order 
you test the piles in. With no time to spare, 
the iron comes to life, and you manage to get the shirt 
flawlessly ironed. The pleased elder and his family show up 
to the party dressed to the nines … well, almost.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many working batteries does the iron need?
Options: A. 2, B. 4, C. 6, D. 8
Correct Option: A

Question 3: How do neutron stars often behave before they collapse? Options: A. They undergo nuclear fission, B. They experience gravitational waves, C. They spin rapidly, D. They emit gamma rays Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the reason for the rapid spin of a neutron star compared to its parent star? Options: A. The increase in mass, B. The decrease in size, C. The change in magnetic field, D. The conservation of angular momentum Correct Option: D
Question 5: What happens to an aging neutron star's furious rotation over billions of years? Options: A. It speeds up, B. It remains the same, C. It increases in size, D. It slows down due to the emission of electromagnetic and gravity waves Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the significance of the detection of a pulsar by astrophysicist Jocelyn Bell in 1967? Options: A. It was the first observation of a binary system, B. It was the first detection of a supernova, C. It was the first observation of a black hole, D. It was the first indirect discovery of a neutron star Correct Option: D

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Ground Truth Question 1, Matched Generated Question 1
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
As dawn breaks over a moveable city 
of ten thousand yurts, Queen Boraqchin is in 
for a rude awakening. A rogue sheep has slipped past her 
servants and guards and bolted into her yurt, where he springs into bed 
and bleats in her ear. Although she’s the formidable khatun 
of the Golden Horde, a huge kingdom in the Mongolian Empire, Boraqchin has a hands-on 
approach to ruling. She’s been married to Batu Khan, the fearsome grandson 
of Genghis Khan himself, since she was fifteen – and while her husband is out on his raids, she juggles the duties of flocks, 
family and empire at home. This makes her the manager – 
and the mover – of a city of thousands. Twice a year, Boraqchin moves the city 
between two seasonal camping grounds. This ensures constant water 
and lush grass in summer, and protection from harsh winds in winter. The whole operation requires 
weeks of strict planning, liaising with the other camps in her 
domain, strategic delegation – and the patience to move at the speed 
of dawdling animals. Today is moving day, and she’ll have to direct throngs of her
ladies, commanders, slaves and animals up the river Volga for the summer. As Boraqchin steps outside, she’s greeted by a commotion – her unwanted visitor is now running 
circles around her stewards. They’re attempting to stow her possessions
securely into wagons. Boraqchin orders them 
to get it under control – but she’s the only one quick 
enough to catch the stray. She next supervises her ladies who are
unpinning her yurt and lifting it onto its custom wagon. It requires a team of twenty oxen to pull, and Boraqchin wouldn’t trust anyone 
to steer it but herself. Next, Boraqchin and her woolly companion 
meet with the guards. She orders them to keep close watch
on her husband's special reception yurt and port-able throne during the journey. They’ll also act as outriders, and she tells them how to secure the 
route, surround her for safety – and keep the animals in check. But when the sheep finally breaks free 
and makes for the fields, the guards can barely keep up as it scampers through crowds 
packing up their yurts. Exasperated, Boraqchin rides down 
to the pastures herself. When she gets there, she catches sight of the troublesome sheep
wriggling into the middle of a flock. When she follows him in, he’s nestled next to a ewe, his mother. She’s pregnant,
and seems to be in pain. With a start, Boraqchin realizes 
that this ewe’s impending delivery has been forgotten in 
the flurry of moving day. There’s no time to find a shepherd – instead, Boraqchin rolls up her sleeves, 
greases her arm and helps the ewe give birth to two new 
additions to the empire. Leaving the lambs and their mother, Boraqchin dashes back to the camp. Here the final touches have 
been put to packing, and vehicles are starting to line up. This vast procession starts with the queen and two hundred wagons 
filled with her treasures. Next up are the junior wives and crew, then the concubines – and this is only Boraqchin's camp. After this comes the second imperial camp led by another senior wife, then two more camps, also led by wives. Boraqchin has been checking in 
with them for weeks to ensure a smooth departure and orderly queue. But they only make up the 
royal portion of the line – behind them winds 
the entire civilian city, which includes holy men 
with portable chapels and mosques, families, tradesmen, and shepherds. Finally, Boraqchin settles into her wagon. It’ll take weeks to reach 
their destination – but over the course of the journey, she’ll keep everyone expertly in check – from her proud children 
and attentive subjects, to the most meandering sheep 
at the back of line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Of which Khanate in the Mongol Empire is Boraqchin the queen?
Options: A. The Chaghatayid Khanate, B. The Great Khanate, C. The Ilkhanate, D. The Golden Horde
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: **Knowledge**: Who is the khatun of the Golden Horde in the Mongolian Empire?
Options: A. Queen Boraqchin, B. Batu Khan, C. Genghis Khan, D. The Grandmother of Batu Khan
Correct Option: A

   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.

   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Ground Truth Question 2, Matched Generated Question 7
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
As dawn breaks over a moveable city 
of ten thousand yurts, Queen Boraqchin is in 
for a rude awakening. A rogue sheep has slipped past her 
servants and guards and bolted into her yurt, where he springs into bed 
and bleats in her ear. Although she’s the formidable khatun 
of the Golden Horde, a huge kingdom in the Mongolian Empire, Boraqchin has a hands-on 
approach to ruling. She’s been married to Batu Khan, the fearsome grandson 
of Genghis Khan himself, since she was fifteen – and while her husband is out on his raids, she juggles the duties of flocks, 
family and empire at home. This makes her the manager – 
and the mover – of a city of thousands. Twice a year, Boraqchin moves the city 
between two seasonal camping grounds. This ensures constant water 
and lush grass in summer, and protection from harsh winds in winter. The whole operation requires 
weeks of strict planning, liaising with the other camps in her 
domain, strategic delegation – and the patience to move at the speed 
of dawdling animals. Today is moving day, and she’ll have to direct throngs of her
ladies, commanders, slaves and animals up the river Volga for the summer. As Boraqchin steps outside, she’s greeted by a commotion – her unwanted visitor is now running 
circles around her stewards. They’re attempting to stow her possessions
securely into wagons. Boraqchin orders them 
to get it under control – but she’s the only one quick 
enough to catch the stray. She next supervises her ladies who are
unpinning her yurt and lifting it onto its custom wagon. It requires a team of twenty oxen to pull, and Boraqchin wouldn’t trust anyone 
to steer it but herself. Next, Boraqchin and her woolly companion 
meet with the guards. She orders them to keep close watch
on her husband's special reception yurt and port-able throne during the journey. They’ll also act as outriders, and she tells them how to secure the 
route, surround her for safety – and keep the animals in check. But when the sheep finally breaks free 
and makes for the fields, the guards can barely keep up as it scampers through crowds 
packing up their yurts. Exasperated, Boraqchin rides down 
to the pastures herself. When she gets there, she catches sight of the troublesome sheep
wriggling into the middle of a flock. When she follows him in, he’s nestled next to a ewe, his mother. She’s pregnant,
and seems to be in pain. With a start, Boraqchin realizes 
that this ewe’s impending delivery has been forgotten in 
the flurry of moving day. There’s no time to find a shepherd – instead, Boraqchin rolls up her sleeves, 
greases her arm and helps the ewe give birth to two new 
additions to the empire. Leaving the lambs and their mother, Boraqchin dashes back to the camp. Here the final touches have 
been put to packing, and vehicles are starting to line up. This vast procession starts with the queen and two hundred wagons 
filled with her treasures. Next up are the junior wives and crew, then the concubines – and this is only Boraqchin's camp. After this comes the second imperial camp led by another senior wife, then two more camps, also led by wives. Boraqchin has been checking in 
with them for weeks to ensure a smooth departure and orderly queue. But they only make up the 
royal portion of the line – behind them winds 
the entire civilian city, which includes holy men 
with portable chapels and mosques, families, tradesmen, and shepherds. Finally, Boraqchin settles into her wagon. It’ll take weeks to reach 
their destination – but over the course of the journey, she’ll keep everyone expertly in check – from her proud children 
and attentive subjects, to the most meandering sheep 
at the back of line.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which river guides Boraqchin’s migration?
Options: A. The Don, B. The Dnieper, C. The Volga, D. The Danube
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: **Knowledge**: What is the name of the river that Queen Boraqchin's procession will travel along?
Options: A. The Volga River, B. The Yangtze River, C. The Mekong River, D. The Amazon River
Correct Option: A

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which river guides Boraqchin’s migration?
Options: A. The Don, B. The Dnieper, C. The Volga, D. The Danube
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the name of the river that Queen Boraqchin's procession will travel along?
Options: A. The Volga River, B. The Yangtze River, C. The Mekong River, D. The Amazon River
Correct Option: A

**Scores**:
- Relevance Score: 0.9000 (The generated question closely aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question, but the wording is slightly different.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 1.0000 (The correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.8000 (The distractors in the generated question are plausible but could be more challenging and relevant to the context. The Yangtze, Mekong, and Amazon rivers are not in the same geographic region as the Volga River.)

additions to the empire. Leaving the lambs and their mother, Boraqchin dashes back to the camp. Here the final touches have 
been put to packing, and vehicles are starting to line up. This vast procession starts with the queen and two hundred wagons 
filled with her treasures. Next up are the junior wives and crew, then the concubines – and this is only Boraqchin's camp. After this comes the second imperial camp led by another senior wife, then two more camps, also led by wives. Boraqchin has been checking in

royal portion of the line – behind them winds 
the entire civilian city, which includes holy men

their destination – but over the course of the journey, she’ll keep everyone expertly in check – from her proud children 
and attentive subjects, to the most meandering sheep 
at the back of line.

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Ground Truth Question 5, Matched Generated Question 9

Question: **Application**: If you were a member of Queen Boraqchin's team, how would you ensure that the city's treasures are safely transported during the move?
Options: A. You would assign a team of guards to escort the wagons, B. You would use a combination of wagons and carts to transport the treasures, C. You would divide the treasures among multiple wagons to spread out the risk, D. You would leave the treasures behind and focus on moving the people
Correct Option: A

Question: Who goes on this migration in addition to Boraqchin?

Question: **Application**: If you were a member of Queen Boraqchin's team, how would you ensure that the city's treasures are safely transported during the move?
Options: A. You would assign a team of guards to escort the wagons, B. You would use a combination of wagons and carts to transport the treasures, C. You would divide the treasures among multiple wagons to spread out the risk, D. You would leave the treasures behind and focus on moving the people
Correct Option: A

**Scores**:
- Relevance Score: 0.2000 (The generated question does not directly align with the content and intent of the ground truth question, which asks about the participants of the migration. The generated question is more focused on the logistics of the move.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 0.0000 (The correct answer options do not match between the two questions.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.8000 (The distractors in the generated question are plausible and require some thought to eliminate.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 0.9000 (The question and options are clear and easy to understand.)
- Total Score: 0.4750

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Ground Truth Question 1, Matched Generated Question 3
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

1. Match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent of the MCQ.

**Transcript**:
In 1982, a young nurse was suffering
from severe, unrelenting depression. She couldn’t work, socialize, or even concentrate well enough
to read the newspaper. One treatment changed everything. After two courses of electroconvulsive
therapy, or ECT, her symptoms lifted. She went back to work, then on to graduate
school, where she earned high grades. At first, she talked openly about
her life changing treatment. But as she realized many people had an
extremely negative impression of ECT, she stopped sharing her experience. ECT carried a deep stigma, leftover from a history that bears little
resemblance to the modern procedure. The therapy was first
used in medicine in 1938. In its early years, doctors administered a
strong electrical current to the brain, causing a whole-body seizure
during which patients might bite their tongues
or even break bones. Modern ECT is very different. While a patient is under 
general anesthesia, electrodes deliver a series
of mild electrical pulses to the brain. This causes huge numbers of neurons
to fire in unison: a brief, controlled seizure. A muscle relaxant keeps spasms
from spreading to the rest of his body. The only physical indication of the
electricity flooding the brain is a twitching foot. The treatment lasts for about a minute,
and most patients are able to resume normal activities about an
hour after each session. ECT is commonly used to treat severe cases
of major depression or bipolar disorder in patients who haven’t responded
to other therapies, or who have had adverse 
reactions to medication. Half or more of those who undergo 
treatment experience an improvement in their symptoms. Most patients treated with ECT have two or
three sessions per week for several weeks. Some begin to notice an improvement
in their symptoms after just one session, while others take longer to respond. Patients often continue less frequent
treatments for several months to a year, and some need occasional maintenance
sessions for the rest of their lives. Modern ECT is much safer than
it used to be, but patients can still 
experience side effects. They may feel achy, fatigued, 
or nauseated right after treatment. Some have trouble remembering what
happened right before a session— for example, what they had for 
dinner the previous evening. Rarely, they might have trouble 
remembering up to weeks and months before. For most patients, this memory
loss does improve over time. What's fascinating is that despite its 
proven track record, we still don't know exactly why ECT works. Neurons in the brain communicate via
electrical signals, which influence our brain chemistry, 
contributing to mood and behavior. The flood of electrical activity sparked
by ECT alters that chemistry. For example, ECT triggers the release
of certain neurotransmitters, molecules that help carry signals between
neurons and influence mental health. ECT also stimulates the flow of hormones
that may help reduce symptoms of depression. Interestingly, ECT maintenance works
better when paired with medication, even in patients who were
resistant to medication before. As we come to a better 
understanding of the brain, we’ll likely be able to make 
ECT even more effective. In 1995, more than a decade after
her first course of ECT, the nurse decided to publish an
account of her experience. Because of the stigma surrounding
the treatment, she worried that doing so
might negatively impact her personal and professional life, but she knew ECT could make a difference
for patients when all else failed. Though misperceptions about ECT persist, accounts like hers have helped make
doctors and patients alike aware of the treatment’s 
life changing potential.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: ECT, once largely stigmatized, has become a mainstream treatment again for depression and mania. About how many patients in the United States are treated each year with this therapy?
Options: A. One thousand, B. One hundred thousand, C. One million, D. One billion
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is a common use of ECT in modern medicine?
Options: A. To treat mild cases of depression, B. To treat severe cases of major depression or bipolar disorder in patients who haven't responded to other therapies, C. To enhance cognitive function in patients with dementia, D. To reduce anxiety in patients with PTSD
Correct Option: B

2. Evaluate each matched MCQ pair based on the following criteria:
   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
   - **Correct Answer Matching (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Check if the correct answer option in the generated question matches the ground truth answer.
   - **Distractor Plausibility (0.0000-1.0000)**: Evaluate the quality of the distractors (incorrect options) in the generated question.
   - **Clarity and Readability (0.0000-1.0000)**: Rate how clear and understandable the question and options are.

**Response Format**:
1. **MCQ Pair**: Display both the Ground Truth and Generated MCQ.
2. **Scores**:
   - Relevance Score: X.XXXX
   - Correct Answer Matching Score: X.XXXX
   - Distractor Plausibility Score: X.XXXX
   - Clarity and Readability Score: X.XXXX
   - Total Score: X.XXXX

Evaluation Response:
**MCQ Pair**:

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: ECT, once largely stigmatized, has become a mainstream treatment again for depression and mania. About how many patients in the United States are treated each year with this therapy?
Options: A. One thousand, B. One hundred thousand, C. One million, D. One billion
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is a common use of ECT in modern medicine?
Options: A. To treat mild cases of depression, B. To treat severe cases of major depression or bipolar disorder in patients who haven't responded to other therapies, C. To enhance cognitive function in patients with dementia, D. To reduce anxiety in patients with PTSD
Correct Option: B

**Scores**:
- Relevance Score: 0.5000 (The generated question is related to the topic of ECT, but it does not directly address the same question as the ground truth MCQ, which is about the number of patients treated with ECT each year.)
- Correct Answer Matching Score: 0.0000 (The correct answer options do not match between the two MCQs.)
- Distractor Plausibility Score: 0.7500 (The distractors in the generated question are plausible and relevant to the topic of ECT, but they could be more challenging and realistic.)
- Clarity and Readability Score: 0.9000 (Both the question and options in the generated MCQ are clear and easy to understand.)
- Total Score: 0.5375

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Ground Truth Question 2, Matched Generated Question 2
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

**Transcript**:
In 1982, a young nurse was suffering
from severe, unrelenting depression. She couldn’t work, socialize, or even concentrate well enough
to read the newspaper. One treatment changed everything. After two courses of electroconvulsive
therapy, or ECT, her symptoms lifted. She went back to work, then on to graduate
school, where she earned high grades. At first, she talked openly about
her life changing treatment. But as she realized many people had an
extremely negative impression of ECT, she stopped sharing her experience. ECT carried a deep stigma, leftover from a history that bears little
resemblance to the modern procedure. The therapy was first
used in medicine in 1938. In its early years, doctors administered a
strong electrical current to the brain, causing a whole-body seizure
during which patients might bite their tongues
or even break bones. Modern ECT is very different. While a patient is under 
general anesthesia, electrodes deliver a series
of mild electrical pulses to the brain. This causes huge numbers of neurons
to fire in unison: a brief, controlled seizure. A muscle relaxant keeps spasms
from spreading to the rest of his body. The only physical indication of the
electricity flooding the brain is a twitching foot. The treatment lasts for about a minute,
and most patients are able to resume normal activities about an
hour after each session. ECT is commonly used to treat severe cases
of major depression or bipolar disorder in patients who haven’t responded
to other therapies, or who have had adverse 
reactions to medication. Half or more of those who undergo 
treatment experience an improvement in their symptoms. Most patients treated with ECT have two or
three sessions per week for several weeks. Some begin to notice an improvement
in their symptoms after just one session, while others take longer to respond. Patients often continue less frequent
treatments for several months to a year, and some need occasional maintenance
sessions for the rest of their lives. Modern ECT is much safer than
it used to be, but patients can still 
experience side effects. They may feel achy, fatigued, 
or nauseated right after treatment. Some have trouble remembering what
happened right before a session— for example, what they had for 
dinner the previous evening. Rarely, they might have trouble 
remembering up to weeks and months before. For most patients, this memory
loss does improve over time. What's fascinating is that despite its 
proven track record, we still don't know exactly why ECT works. Neurons in the brain communicate via
electrical signals, which influence our brain chemistry, 
contributing to mood and behavior. The flood of electrical activity sparked
by ECT alters that chemistry. For example, ECT triggers the release
of certain neurotransmitters, molecules that help carry signals between
neurons and influence mental health. ECT also stimulates the flow of hormones
that may help reduce symptoms of depression. Interestingly, ECT maintenance works
better when paired with medication, even in patients who were
resistant to medication before. As we come to a better 
understanding of the brain, we’ll likely be able to make 
ECT even more effective. In 1995, more than a decade after
her first course of ECT, the nurse decided to publish an
account of her experience. Because of the stigma surrounding
the treatment, she worried that doing so
might negatively impact her personal and professional life, but she knew ECT could make a difference
for patients when all else failed. Though misperceptions about ECT persist, accounts like hers have helped make
doctors and patients alike aware of the treatment’s 
life changing potential.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the name of a typical muscle relaxant used to make ECT safe by essentially inducing a brief paralysis to the extremities?
Options: A. Succinylcholine, B. Atropine, C. Benadryl, D. Ketamine
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQ**:
Question: What is the primary difference between modern ECT and its early years?
Options: A. Modern ECT is administered under general anesthesia, while early ECT was not, B. Modern ECT uses a stronger electrical current, while early ECT used a weaker current, C. Modern ECT is more targeted in its delivery of electrical pulses to the brain, D. Modern ECT requires more sessions than early ECT
Correct Option: C

from severe, unrelenting depression. She couldn’t work, socialize, or even concentrate well enough

therapy, or ECT, her symptoms lifted. She went back to work, then on to graduate

and most patients are able to resume normal activities about an

in their symptoms after just one session, while others take longer to respond. Patients often continue less frequent

contributing to mood and behavior. The flood of electrical activity sparked
by ECT alters that chemistry. For example, ECT triggers the release
of certain neurotransmitters, molecules that help carry signals between
neurons and influence mental health. ECT also stimulates the flow of hormones
that may help reduce symptoms of depression. Interestingly, ECT maintenance works
better when paired with medication, even in patients who were
resistant to medication before. As we come to a better

doctors and patients alike aware of the treatment’s 
life changing potential.

Correct Option: B

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Ground Truth Question 4, Matched Generated Question 1
Evaluation Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript, a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), and a set of generated MCQs, your task is to:

**Transcript**:
In 1982, a young nurse was suffering
from severe, unrelenting depression. She couldn’t work, socialize, or even concentrate well enough
to read the newspaper. One treatment changed everything. After two courses of electroconvulsive
therapy, or ECT, her symptoms lifted. She went back to work, then on to graduate

Scoring Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Ground Truth Question 5, Matched Generated Question 3

   - **Relevance (0.0000 - 1.0000)**: Assess how closely the generated question aligns with the content and intent of the ground truth question.
